article_text:
Covering more of California

Photo: Paul Chinn, The Chronicle Rich Manuzon sets up a Covered California health care coverage...

California has been a national success story when it comes to implementing the Affordable Care Act. While other states — and, for a time, the federal government — were fumbling their website rollouts and dealing with political pushback from their own citizens and legislators, California was calmly setting up its health care exchange and expanding its Medi-Cal rolls. Following the long, agonizing Washington battle to achieve passage of the Affordable Care Act, Covered California (the state administration’s offshoot) seemed to be one of the nation’s brightest stars.

article_metadata.sailthru.author: San Francisco Chronicle
article_metadata.description: While other states — and, for a time, the federal government — were fumbling their website rollouts and dealing with political pushback from their own citizens and legislators, California was calmly setting up its health care exchange and expanding its Medi-Cal rolls.  Following the long, agonizing Washington battle to achieve passage of the Affordable Care Act, Covered California (the state administration’s offshoot) seemed to be one of the nation’s brightest stars.  [...] though Medi-Cal enrollment has soared following the state’s coverage expansion — some 4 million Californians have enrolled in Medi-Cal over the past two years — there’s still an enormous segment of the population that’s not covered by any health care plan at all.  [...] some percentage of residents will always choose not to enroll in a health care plan — even if there are government subsidies available (there are), and even if refusing to do so results in a tax penalty (it does).  [...] while it’s frustrating that there are some 750,000 Californians who are eligible for subsidized coverage and still haven’t signed up, there’s no way to reach everyone short of compelling health care coverage (via a single-payer program, for instance).  A few efforts already under way include increasing premium subsidies (San Francisco’s Board of Supervisors recently voted to do this with the Healthy San Francisco program) and reducing service overuse (the California Public Employees’ Retirement System, the State Department of Health Care Services and Covered California have a working group to address overuse for lower back pain, cesarean sections and other common conditions).  [...] the bill’s author, state Sen. Ricardo Lara, D-Bell Gardens (Los Angeles County), is facing an uphill battle when it comes to allowing all undocumented Californians to either sign up for Medi-Cal or buy a plan through the state exchange.
article_metadata.author.name: San Francisco Chronicle

[...] though Medi-Cal enrollment has soared following the state’s coverage expansion — some 4 million Californians have enrolled in Medi-Cal over the past two years — there’s still an enormous segment of the population that’s not covered by any health care plan at all.  [...] some percentage of residents will always choose not to enroll in a health care plan — even if there are government subsidies available (there are), and even if refusing to do so results in a tax penalty (it does).  [...] while it’s frustrating that there are some 750,000 Californians who are eligible for subsidized coverage and still haven’t signed up, there’s no way to reach everyone short of compelling health care coverage (via a single-payer program, for instance).  A few efforts already under way include increasing premium subsidies (San Francisco’s Board of Supervisors recently voted to do this with the Healthy San Francisco program) and reducing service overuse (the California Public Employees’ Retirement System, the State Department of Health Care Services and Covered California have a working group to address overuse for lower back pain, cesarean sections and other common conditions).  [...] the bill’s author, state Sen. Ricardo Lara, D-Bell Gardens (Los Angeles County), is facing an uphill battle when it comes to allowing all undocumented Californians to either sign up for Medi-Cal or buy a plan through the state exchange.
